abstract.para: Learn about the basic concepts of &sudo; and how it works.

topic.para: &sudo; is a Linux command that is used to temporarily execute programs as another user. It is the abbreviation for super user do and can be used to run a command as &rootuser; user.

As a normal user on Linux, you have reduced permissions which is sufficient for most of the tasks. The &rootuser; user is the Linux superuser and the equivalent to the administrator who has maximum permissions to do anything to the system.

For security reasons, all &productname; systems separate the normal user from the &rootuser; user. For example, as a normal user, you cannot write to system directories or install programs. Any user with access to the &rootuser; password can gain this privileges and accidentally or maliciously break the system. For example, you are logged in as normal user and accidentally browsing to a malicious website. An attacker cannot install malware on your system behind your back, as you are logged in as normal user without admin permissions.
It is not recommended to be logged in as root permanently. A safer approach is logging in as a normal user and running a restricted command prefaced with &sudo;.

On a single-user machine, where you have set your own root password, you can administer your system using &sudo; and configure &sudo; yourself. For more information about how to configure &sudo; refer to ???.

In a multi-user environment, such as in companies, the &sudo; privileges are managed by a system administrator and the permissions of the &rootuser; user can be restricted. For example, even when running a command with &sudo; you may not be allowed to change certain system directories or files.

note.para: To use the &sudo; command, you have to have the &sudo; package available on your system. This is installed on all &productname; distributions by default.
